text: Panther wormsHooge, M.D., Wallberg, A., Todt, C., Maloy, A.P., Jondelius, U., & Tyler, S.D. (2007). A revision of the systematics of panther worms (Hofstenia spp., Acoela), with notes on color variation and genetic variation within the genus. Hydrobiologia, 592, 439-454. belong to Hofsteniidae, a family of acoels. This family contains seven species in three genera. The size of this worm is 500 μm for adults, 100 μm for embryos. They have a simple nervous system and a bowel sac with no way out. ==Genera== There are three genera in the family Hofsteniidae. *Hofstenia Bock, 1923 *Hofsteniola Papi, 1957 *Marcusiola Steinböck, 1966 ==Species== There are seven species in the family Hofsteniidae. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left;" |- !scope="col"| Name !scope="col"| Image !scope="col"| Distribution !scope="col"| Description |- |scope="row" align="left"|Hofstenia arabiensis Beltagi & Mandura, 1991 | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"|Hofstenia atroviridis Bock, 1923 | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"| Hofstenia beltagii Steinböck, 1966 | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"|Hofstenia miamia Correa, 1960 ('three-banded panther worm') | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"|Hofstenia minuta Palombi, 1928 | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"| Hofsteniola pardii Papi 1957 | | | |- |scope="row" align="left"|Marcusiola tinga (Marcus, 1957) | | | |- |} ==Notes== ==References== Category:Acoelomorphs
